awd_titl_txt: EXP:  Collaborative Research:  Cyber-enabled Teacher Discourse Analytics to Empower Teacher Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will use multiple sources of middle school classroom data to give feedback and assessment information to teachers so that their teaching ability is enhanced. The data includes anonymized student performance data (grades and standardized test results) and anonymized existing audio recordings of classroom discussions between students and teachers. The audio data will be used to analyze the student-teacher discussions for effectiveness of the student-teacher discussions in student learning. As the effectiveness measures are developed, feedback for instructional improvement will be provided to the teachers in a design cycle for continuous improvement. The technological innovations are in the analysis of the student-teacher discussions, in natural language understanding of student-teacher discussions, and in machine learning to classify effective from non-effective student-teacher discussions.

This project will advance cyber-enabled, teacher analytics as a new genre of technology that provides automated feedback on teacher performance with the goal of improving teaching effectiveness and student achievement. The exemplary implementation will autonomously analyze audio from real-world English and language arts classes for indicators of effective discourse to enable a new paradigm of datadriven reflective practice. The project emphasizes six theoretical dimensions of discourse linked to student achievement growth: goal clarity, disciplinary concepts, and strategy use for teacher-led discourse, and challenge, connection, and elaborated feedback for transactional discourse. The innovation aims to help teachers develop expertise on these dimensions and will be developed and tested in 9th grade classrooms in Western Pennsylvania. The team will first generate initial insights on how teacher discourse predicts student achievement via a re-analysis of large volumes (128 hours) of existing classroom audio. Next, they will design and iteratively refine hardware/software interfaces for efficient,flexible, scalable audio data collection by teachers. The data will be used to computationally model dimensions of effective discourse by combining linguistic, discursive, acoustic, and contextual analysis of audio with supervised and semi-supervised deep recurrent neural networks. The model-based estimates will be incorporated into an interactive analytic/visualization platform to promote data-driven reflective practice. After refinement via design studies, the impact of the innovation on instructional improvement and student literacy outcomes will be evaluated in a randomized control trial. Finally, generalizable insights will be identified at every stage of the project to promote transferability to future cyber-enabled, teacher-analytics technologies.

por.por_cntn:
Overview. The project advances cyber-enabled, teacher analytics as a new genre of technology that provides automated feedback on teacher discourse with the goal of improving teaching effectiveness and student achievement. The exemplary implementation autonomously analyzes audio from real-world English and language arts classes for indicators of effective discourse to enable a new paradigm of data-driven reflective practice. The project emphasizes theoretical dimensions of teacher-led and transactional discourse linked to student achievement growth such as goal clarity, use of disciplinary concepts, strategy elaborated feedback, and open-ended (authentic) questions. The technological innovation called the Teacher Talk Tool provides teachers with fully-automated, fine-grained, artificial-intelligence driven feedback on the above dimensions of teacher discourse to enable reflection, sense-making, and uptake. The basic research program and corresponding cyberinnovation tool was developed and tested with middle- and high-school school teachers in Western Pennsylvania.

 

We accomplished the following research objectives:      

  1. Enabling teacher-focused data collection. We designed and iteratively refined hardware and software interfaces for usable, efficient, flexible, and scalable audio data collection by teachers, while also using the technology to collect a large (128 classroom observations) data set of high-fidelity classroom audio.
  2. Advancing basic research on effective teaching. We annotated and analyzed the data set from #1 to advance basic research on dimensions of instruction that are malleable and expected to predict student achievement growth. We also pioneered a new semi-automated methodology to accelerate human coding and analysis of classroom discourse.
  3. Automated algorithms for classroom discourse analysis. We combined advances in deep (machine) learning with speech and language processing techniques (from #1) to develop computational models of that estimate the prevalence of components of effective teaching (#2) from noisy real-world teacher speech.
  4. Enabling data-driven reflective practice via the Teacher Talk Tool. We designed and refined an analytic/visualization interface to provide teachers with automated formative feedback on the prevalence of their own discourse to support data-driven reflective practice. We also conducted a longitudinal user study to investigate teachers’ usage patterns and perceptions of the tool.
  5. Promoting generalizability and transferability. We identified generalizable insights at each project step to facilitate transferability to additional cyber-enabled, teacher analytics technologies. We published eight peer-reviewed papers with an additional two papers under review. We also disseminated our findings in non-archival conference presentations, invited keynotes, and invited talks/panels. Other artifacts include a dataset of classroom audio, computational models of discourse, and a new cyberlearning technology called the Teacher Talk Tool for which a patent application has been filed.

 

Intellectual Merit

From a theoretical perspective, the project helped develop a basic understanding of the relationship between teacher discourse and student learning by integrating multiple theoretical frameworks of effective discourse. It also led to the development of an agnostic theory of teacher feedback as a key component of teacher professional development.  Relatedly, based on this and other recent studies, we hypothesize that emphasizing choice in professional feedback systems may fundamentally enhance user engagement. Methodologically, the project demonstrated that through advances in digital signal processing, natural language processing, and machine learning, it is possible to model fundamental qualities of teacher talk without labor intensive in-person observation, even in the context of noisy real-world classrooms. From a practical perspective, the project demonstrated that providing fine-grained, objective, formative feedback can empower teachers to refine their own instruction, thereby advancing data-driven reflective practice as a new paradigm of teacher learning.

Broader Impacts

●      With respect to interdisciplinary training, the project has supported training of five graduate students, undergraduate students, and multiple research staff. Students were trained in the interdisciplinary fields of computer science, the learning sciences, discourse analysis, and the sociology of education.

●      With respect to broadening participation of underrepresented groups in science, the project supported the research of one women PhD computer science student.

●      The project team worked closely with several ELA middle- and high- school teachers in co-developing and testing the Teacher Talk Tool 

●      Longer term broader impacts include improving literacy outcomes in U.S. students by improving teacher instructional effectiveness.

●      Lastly, by targeting classroom talk, a fundamental dimension of instruction, the research can impact teaching effectiveness in a wide range of domains including STEM and beyond.
